{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18477,"attracts":["Birds","Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus mongolica, commonly known as the Mongolian oak, requires moderate watering. It is important to water the tree deeply to encourage root growth, especially during its establishment period in the first few years after planting. Once established, the Mongolian oak is relatively drought-tolerant, but during prolonged dry spells or extreme heat, occasional deep watering will benefit the tree. Avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. Always allow the topsoil to dry out between watering sessions, and ensure the planting site has good drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus mongolica thrives best in full sun conditions, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. Adequate sunlight ensures optimal growth and the development of a strong structure. The tree can tolerate partial shade, but this may affect the density of its foliage and overall vigor. When planting a Mongolian oak, choose a site that receives ample sunlight throughout the day. In areas with extreme heat, some afternoon shade can help reduce stress, but generally, full sun is ideal for the healthiest growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus mongolica should primarily be done during the late winter or early spring when the tree is dormant. This is to avoid stress and to promote healthy growth. The main goal of pruning this oak is to remove dead, diseased, or damaged branches, as well as to improve the tree's structural integrity and allow sunlight to penetrate the canopy. Avoid heavy pruning, as oaks can be sensitive to severe cuts. Light trimming and thinning can help maintain the tree's shape and health, encouraging a robust branching structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mongolian Oak","description":"Quercus mongolica, commonly known as Mongolian oak, is a species of oak native to Japan, southern Kuriles, Sakhalin, Manchuria, central and northern China, Korea, eastern Mongolia, and eastern Siberia. The species can grow to be 30 m tall.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan","Korea","Russia"],"other_name":["Mongolian Oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Gall wasps","Oak lace bug"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus mongolica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18876,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aloe microstigma is a drought-tolerant succulent that requires minimal watering. It is essential to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. Typically, watering every two to three weeks during the growing season (spring and summer) is sufficient. Reduce watering frequency in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. Ensure the pot has good drainage to prevent root rot, as Aloe microstigma is susceptible to overwatering. Rainwater or distilled water is preferable to tap water, which may contain minerals that can accumulate in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aloe microstigma thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate some direct sun, especially in the morning or late afternoon. Ideally, it should be placed in a location where it receives at least six hours of bright light daily. A south or east-facing window is often perfect. In particularly hot climates, protect the plant from intense midday sun to avoid leaf burn. If growing indoors, turning the plant regularly ensures all sides receive equal light exposure, promoting balanced growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aloe microstigma is generally minimal, as these succulents maintain their shape naturally. However, dead or damaged leaves can be removed to improve overall appearance and health. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut unwanted leaves close to the plant's base, taking care not to damage surrounding foliage. Pruning is best done during the growing season to encourage quicker healing and growth. Additionally, remove any offsets to prevent overcrowding and to propagate new plants if desired."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"small-spotted aloe","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["small-spotted aloe"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Offset Propagation","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Aloe microstigma"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18383,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Montagnea arenaria, commonly known as the desert fungus, does not require traditional watering methods as it is a fungus. This species thrives in arid desert conditions, often appearing following rare rainfalls. Therefore, no supplemental watering is needed when cultivating or observing it in its natural habitat. If you are trying to cultivate it for research purposes, maintaining a dry environment with occasional light misting to simulate natural desert rainfall might mimic its natural growth conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Montagnea arenaria is adapted to survive in full sunlight typical of desert environments. It thrives in open, sun-exposed conditions with minimal shade. If attempting to study or cultivate this fungus, it is critical to replicate high-light conditions without intense heat, which might dry out the substrate too quickly. Nonetheless, it typically benefits from natural desert-style sun exposure during its growth cycle."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As Montagnea arenaria is a fungus, traditional pruning practices do not apply. Its lifecycle and growth are dictated by natural environmental conditions rather than human intervention. If you're studying this fungus, your focus should be on ensuring appropriate conditions for its sporulation and growth rather than any form of pruning. Simply observing its development and ensuring a clear area for its growth are the main considerations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Desert Inkcap","description":"Montagnea arenaria is a species of secotioid fungus in the Agaricaceae family. Originally named Agaricus arenarius by Augustin Pyramus de Candolle in 1815, it was transferred to the genus Montagnea by Sanford Myron Zeller in 1943. The species is characterized by a cap that has an apical disc, radial gills, a hymenophore, and spores with a prominent germ pore.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southwestern United States","Northern Mexico"],"other_name":["Desert Inkcap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Montagnea arenaria"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18680,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cyperus ustulatus, commonly known as Giant Umbrella Sedge, prefers consistent moisture in its growing environment. It thrives best when the soil is kept consistently wet, but it should not be waterlogged. Watering should be thorough, ensuring the water reaches all parts of the roots. In dry conditions or during prolonged dry spells, increase watering frequency to prevent the plant from drying out. Reduced watering is necessary in cooler months to prevent root rot, but the soil should still remain moist. Use a soil moisture meter to monitor moisture levels and adjust watering accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cyperus ustulatus requires ample sunlight to thrive, making it well-suited for full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, it can benefit from partial shade during the hottest part of the day to prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, place the plant near a bright window where it will receive indirect sunlight throughout the day. Ensure the light is not too harsh, as excessively strong sunlight can damage the foliage. Adjusting its location according to seasonal light changes can ensure optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cyperus ustulatus involves removing dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth and improve appearance. This is typically done in early spring or late winter. Using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears, cut back any brown or yellowing foliage at the base. This helps the plant to focus its energy on new growth. For maintaining a tidy shape, you can trim off any unusually tall stems that disrupt the plant's natural form. Regular cleaning and removal of fallen foliage around the plant's base is also recommended to prevent fungal issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Giant Umbrella Sedge","description":"Cyperus ustulatus, also known as giant umbrella-sedge or coastal cutty grass is a species of sedge native to New Zealand. C. ustulatus generally grows in coastal or lowland areas near water on North Island and the Kermadec Islands.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Giant Umbrella Sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cyperus ustulatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19473,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Protea magnifica prefers moderate watering. It should be watered deeply but infrequently to mimic its native South African conditions. Allow the top soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot, as these plants are quite drought-tolerant. Ensure the pot or ground soil has excellent drainage to prevent excess moisture accumulation. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water more frequently if the weather is particularly hot or dry. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is not actively growing. Be cautious with over-watering as it is one of the most common mistakes in protea care."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Protea magnifica thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. In its native habitat, it grows in high-altitude regions exposed to plenty of sunshine, so it needs similar conditions when cultivated in gardens or pots. A location with a southern exposure is ideal to ensure it receives adequate light. If you are growing this plant indoors, choose a spot close to a window that receives bright light. In areas with intense sun, afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf burn, especially during hot summers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for maintaining the shape and encouraging blooms in Protea magnifica. Prune lightly after flowering to remove spent blooms and promote bushier growth. Cut back the flowering stems to a healthy set of leaves, but avoid cutting into the hardwood as this may damage the plant. Regularly removing dead or damaged branches throughout the year will help keep the plant healthy. Pruning also improves air circulation within the bush, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. Avoid heavy pruning as Protea can respond poorly to it, hindering future bloom production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Queen Sugarbush","description":"Protea magnifica, commonly known as the queen sugarbush or queen protea, is a shrub of the Proteaceae family that is native to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Queen Sugarbush"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot","Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Protea magnifica"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Pruning can be done throughout the growing season, but it's best to avoid major cutbacks during the dormant period in winter. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent tearing and disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"wavyleaf basketgrass","description":"Oplismenus undulatifolius, commonly known as wavyleaf basketgrass, is a species of perennial grass from the Poaceae family that is native to South Asia, East Asia, Southeast Asia, Australia, and Southern Africa. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18182,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Kalanchoe tomentosa, or Panda Plant, requires infrequent watering. As a succulent, it's well-suited to dry conditions and can suffer from overwatering, which may lead to root rot. Water the plant thoroughly, allowing excess water to drain away, and wait until the soil is completely dry before watering again. This generally means watering it once every two to three weeks, but the frequency can depend on factors like humidity and temperature. Reduce watering in winter when the plant's growth slows down. Always ensure the plant is in a pot with good drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kalanchoe tomentosa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It's best to place it near a window where it can receive plenty of light, but be careful to avoid direct sunlight, especially in the summer, as this can scorch the leaves. If the plant receives too little light, it may become leggy and lose its characteristic fuzziness. In winter, when light levels are lower, you may want to move it to a brighter spot to ensure it still gets enough light to maintain its health. Adjust placements gradually to prevent shock."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kalanchoe tomentosa involves removing any dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and health. It's best done using sterilized scissors or pruning shears to prevent disease. You can also pinch off the growing tips to encourage a bushier growth habit, but be careful not to over-prune, as these plants grow slowly. The best time to prune is during the plant's active growing season in the spring and summer. Always make clean cuts, and if you wish to propagate, allow the cuttings to callous before planting."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Panda Plant","description":"Kalanchoe tomentosa or panda plant, also known as pussy ears and chocolate soldier, is a succulent plant in the genus Kalanchoe. A native of Madagascar, it is a fairly popular houseplant on account of its small size, ease of care, and dark-red rimmed foliage.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green, grey-green, with red or brown edges"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Madagascar"],"other_name":["Panda Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Leaf propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Kalanchoe tomentosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Cactus-specific soil"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18980,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Anemone sylvestris prefers consistently moist soil, but it should not be waterlogged. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells or in containers, ensuring that the top inch of soil remains moderately moist. Reduce watering frequency in the winter months when the plant is dormant. It's crucial to allow excess water to drain away to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and keep roots cool. Adjust watering based on your climate conditions and the specific environment where the plant is growing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Anemone sylvestris thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. In cooler climates, it can handle full sun and benefits from about 6 hours of sunlight per day. However, in hotter regions, it fares better with afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch and to keep the soil from drying out too quickly. Ideally, plant it in a location that receives morning sun and filtered light in the hotter part of the day. Adapting to both sun and partial shade makes it versatile for various garden settings."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anemone sylvestris is relatively straightforward and centers around removing spent flowers and dead or damaged foliage. During the blooming season, deadhead faded flowers to encourage more blooms and prevent the plant from going to seed early. At the end of the growing season, typically in late autumn, cut back the foliage to the ground to tidy up the plant and prepare it for winter dormancy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so a thorough watering every 2-3 weeks during the growing season is usually sufficient. During the dormant winter months, water even less, maybe once every 4-6 weeks. Ensure that the pot or ground provides excellent drainage to prevent standing water and protect the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pittocaulon praecox thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. When grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window. If sufficient sunlight is not available, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to maintain its growth and development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pittocaulon praecox is essential to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune during its dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to enhance air circulation and sunlight penetration within the canopy. This plant doesn't require regular pruning, so only cut back lightly to maintain its natural form. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts just above a healthy bud or branch junction, reducing the risk of disease. Always avoid cutting into the older, woody parts, as this can harm its growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Broomstick Tree","description":"Pittocaulon praecox is the type species for the genus Pittocaulon and family Asteraceae. If grown indoors, place it in a spot with bright, indirect light to mimic its preferred natural settings, ensuring the plant remains vibrant and healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Primula pauciflora involves regularly deadheading spent blooms to encourage further flowering and maintain plant aesthetics. This can be done by pinching off the flower stems down to the base without damaging surrounding foliage. In shadier areas, the plant may not bloom as profusely, so try to provide as much natural light as possible without exposing it to overheating. Outdoors, a spot with dappled sunlight or partial shade is generally suitable for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clerodendrum chinense is crucial for maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. The best time to prune is in early spring before the plant starts its new growth cycle. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches first. Trim back overgrown or leggy stems to encourage bushier growth. It's also helpful to prune the plant lightly after flowering to maintain its size and shape. Make sure to clean your pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18981,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fragaria viridis, commonly known as the wild strawberry, prefers consistently moist soil to thrive, especially during its growing period. Regular watering is crucial, ensuring the soil is not waterlogged but remains slightly moist. If planted outdoors, watering frequency may decrease after establishment as long as rainfall is adequate. During dry spells or in potted plants, increase watering to meet soil moisture needs. Be cautious to allow the top layer of soil to dry slightly between waterings to avoid root rot. A layer of mulch can help retain moisture effectively and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fragaria viridis thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and fruit production. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense sun and prevent the soil from drying out excessively. When choosing a planting site, ensure the location receives adequate sunlight exposure throughout the growing season. In less sunny regions, prioritize maximizing exposure to morning sunlight to stimulate early-day growth and fruit development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Fragaria viridis helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. After fruiting, remove any dead or yellowing leaves to prevent disease and improve airflow. Runners, or stolons, can be trimmed back to prevent overcrowding, especially if propagation is not desired. In late autumn or early spring, cut back the foliage to prepare for new growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and disease risk. Regular pruning promotes a robust, productive plant and can stimulate growth of new fruiting stems."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"green strawberry","description":"Fragaria viridis is a species of strawberry native to Europe and central Asia. It has fruits with fine flavour. They have surprisingly little of the usual strawberry aroma, but a refreshing acidity, and sometimes ripen without becoming red. It's crucial to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the dormant phase, typically in the summer, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. Ensure the pot has proper drainage to prevent standing water at the roots, which can lead to rot. Monitor humidity levels as well, as the plant prefers a moderately humid environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Freesia leichtlinii thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It performs best with ample light but should be shielded from harsh, direct afternoon sun which can scorch the leaves. Ideally, place the plant in an area where it can receive filtered light for most of the day, such as near an east or west-facing window. In zones where sunlight is less intense, a south-facing window can also work well. During its dormant phase, which typically coincides with hot summer months, reduce exposure to direct sunlight to allow the plant to rest."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Freesia leichtlinii is key to encouraging a healthy growth cycle and abundant flowering. After the flowering period, remove spent blooms to prevent the plant from wasting energy on seed production. This deadheading process will also promote more blooms. After the foliage has turned yellow and died back naturally, typically in early summer, it can be cut off at the base. This signals the plant's entry into dormancy. Avoid cutting green leaves as they are important for storing energy in the corms for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dune Kammetjie","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Dune Kammetjie"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Corm Offsets"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Freesia leichtlinii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19474,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Protea speciosa, like many proteas, thrives in well-draining soil and does not require frequent watering. During dry spells or in very hot weather, water once every two weeks to maintain soil moisture, but ensure it's not waterlogged. During cooler weather, watering can be reduced. The plant is more drought-tolerant once established, so it's crucial to watch indicators like drooping leaves as a sign of too little water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Protea speciosa needs plenty of sunlight to thrive, preferring full sun exposure for most of the day. It's best planted in a location where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade can result in sparse blooming and leggy growth. In excessively hot regions, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. Ensure that its location has adequate drainage and is not sitting in low areas where water may pool, as this species is sensitive to excessive moisture."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Protea speciosa is vital for maintaining its shape and encouraging robust flowering. After the blooming period, cut back the stems that have finished flowering to a node just above the leaf joint. This encourages new growth and more blooms for the next season. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems throughout the year. Keep in mind that excessive pruning can harm the plant, so be moderate. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring, before the new growth cycle begins."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brownbeard Sugarbush","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Brownbeard Sugarbush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Protea speciosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18478,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Alocasia odora, commonly known as Elephant Ear, requires consistent moisture to thrive. Water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch; overwatering can lead to root rot. It's important to ensure that your pot has good drainage to avoid water logging. Reduce watering during the cooler months when the plant's growth naturally slows down. If you're unsure, it's better to underwater slightly than overwater. Using purified or rainwater can help prevent mineral buildup from tap water, which may harm the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Alocasia odora prefers bright, indirect sunlight, similar to its natural habitat under the tropical canopy. Direct sunlight can scorch its leaves, so it's best placed near a window with filtered light or in a shaded spot outdoors. If indoors, east or north-facing windows are ideal as they provide softer morning light. If you notice the leaves are reaching or leaning towards the light source, consider rotating the plant periodically. In cloudy or dim-light periods, supplemental lighting with fluorescent or LED grow lights can help maintain its vibrant growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Alocasia odora involves removing dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthier growth. Use sterilized pruning shears to cut the leaves at the base, where they meet the stem. It's important not to cut too close to the main stem to avoid damage. Regularly check for yellowing leaves, as these can be a sign the plant is shedding old growth for new. Pruning not only tidies up the plant but also improves air circulation, which is vital to prevent disease. Always wear gloves since the plant's sap can irritate the skin."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Asian Taro","description":"Alocasia odora (also called night-scented lily, Asian taro or giant upright elephant ear) is a flowering plant native to East and Southeast Asia (Japan, China, Indochina, Assam, Bangladesh, Borneo, Taiwan). In Manipur, local name is Hoomu. Alocasia odora (called Ray) can be used as medicine for the treatment of common cold in North Vietnam.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia","East Asia"],"other_name":["Asian Taro"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Alocasia odora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19769,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Papaver cambricum, commonly known as the Welsh Poppy, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. It thrives in environments where it can remain adequately hydrated without becoming waterlogged. During the growing season, especially in dry spells, you should water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil is not allowed to dry out completely. However, care should be taken to avoid overwatering, as the plant does not tolerate soggy conditions. In cooler climates or during cooler seasons, less frequent watering may be necessary, as the soil retains moisture longer. A layer of mulch can help maintain soil moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Papaver cambricum thrives in partial shade, making it a versatile plant for gardens that do not receive full sun. It prefers locations where it can receive dappled sunlight or bright indirect light throughout the day. While it can tolerate some direct morning or late afternoon sun, intense midday sun in hot climates may stress the plant, causing wilting. However, it generally handles varying light conditions well, making it suitable for underplanting among shrubs or trees, or in other shaded garden spots. In cooler, northern climates, it may tolerate more sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Papaver cambricum involves the removal of dead or fading flowers to encourage continued blooming. This process, known as deadheading, can prevent the plant from using energy to produce seeds and instead focus on growing more flowers. Once the flowering season ends, you can cut back the plant to the ground to tidy the garden and prepare for the next growing season. If you wish to control its spread, remove any unwanted seedlings, as it can self-seed prolifically. Regular pruning helps maintain its appearance and overall plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Welsh Poppy","description":"Meconopsis cambrica, the Welsh poppy, is a perennial flowering plant in the poppy family Papaveraceae. It has yellow to orange flowers and is widely grown as a garden plant. It is a native of damp, rocky sites in upland areas of Western Europe from the British Isles to the Iberian Peninsula. It has been used since 2006 as the basis for the logo of the political party Plaid Cymru.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western Europe","Iberian Peninsula"],"other_name":["Welsh Poppy"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Papaver cambricum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19275,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Olea capensis, commonly known as the African ironwood, requires moderate watering. These trees are drought-tolerant once established, so it is essential to let the soil dry out partially between watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, especially in poorly draining soils. During the rainy season, natural rainfall may suffice, but during dry spells or particularly hot weather, supplemental watering may be necessary to maintain soil moisture. It is important to water deeply, targeting the root zone, to encourage deep root growth, which enhances the plant's drought resistance. Regularly check the soil's moisture level to prevent over or underwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Olea capensis thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. These conditions promote the development of a strong, healthy structure and dense foliage. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch and reduce water loss through evaporation. However, too much shade can cause the plant to become leggy as it attempts to reach for more light. Therefore, providing a balance of sunlight and partial shade is key to growing a robust Olea capensis."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Olea capensis is primarily done to maintain its shape and remove dead or diseased wood. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Regular pruning helps prevent the tree from becoming too dense, allowing light and air to penetrate, which reduces the risk of fungal diseases. They perform best when planted in a location that receives full sun for the majority of the day. A southern or western exposure is ideal to provide adequate light. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent heat stress. However, insufficient sunlight can lead to weak growth and poor flowering. Ensure they are in a bright, open area for optimal results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gladiolus Ã— hortulanus involves cutting back the plants as they finish flowering. Remove spent flower spikes by cutting them back to just above the foliage, which encourages bulbs to store energy for next year's blooms. It's crucial to leave the foliage intact until it yellows and dies back naturally, as the leaves are essential for photosynthesis and nutrient storage. In fall or after the first frost, trim back any remaining dead or yellowing foliage at the soil level. Additionally, dig up the corms for storage in colder climates to protect them from winter damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Large-flowered Gladiolus","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Various (often pink, red, purple, white, yellow)","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa","Europe"],"other_name":["Large-flowered Gladiolus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Thrips","Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Corms","Offsets"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Gladiolus Ã— hortulanus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18682,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dianella nigra, also known as New Zealand blueberry, requires moderate watering. It's important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the warmer months, you may need to water it more frequently, especially if it's grown in full sun, as the soil will dry out faster. Reduce watering during the cooler months to prevent overwatering and root rot. Check the top inch of soil; if it feels dry to the touch, then itâ€™s time to water again. Mulching can help retain moisture and keep the roots cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dianella nigra thrives in partial shade to full sun, making it versatile for different garden settings. In its native range, it often grows in shaded or semi-shaded areas, so partial shade can replicate its natural conditions and prevent leaf scorch. However, it can tolerate full sun exposure, particularly in cooler climates. If planted in a region with very hot summers, providing some afternoon shade will help prevent the leaves from becoming scorched and drying out excessively, ensuring the plant remains vibrant and healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dianella nigra is minimal, typically done to maintain the desired shape and remove any damaged or dead leaves. This can generally be done at any time of the year. However, most gardeners find late winter to early spring ideal for a more comprehensive tidy-up, as it encourages new growth. Simply cut back any scraggly or damaged growth down to the base or healthy leaves. It's also beneficial to remove any flower stalks after blooming to conserve the plant's energy and maintain its aesthetic appeal."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Ink Berry","description":"Dianella nigra, (turutu in MÄori, New Zealand blueberry or ink berry) is a perennial herb of the family Asphodelaceae, subfamily Hemerocallidoideae, found in New Zealand. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19475,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rubus pectinellus, like many other shrubs, prefers a consistent level of moisture in the soil. Ensure the planting area is well-drained, as waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. Water the plant thoroughly once a week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the hotter months or in drought conditions, increase the frequency to maintain adequate soil moisture. Avoid overhead watering to reduce the risk of fungal diseases; instead, water at the base of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus pectinellus thrives best in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions with very hot summers, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch and excessive transpiration. If planted in too much shade, the plant may become leggy, produce fewer flowers, and have reduced fruit yield. Ensure that the planting location provides adequate sunlight and air circulation to maintain a healthy plant structure and vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus pectinellus is crucial to maintain its shape and health. The best time to prune is in late winter to early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or diseased wood, which helps to improve air circulation and reduce disease. Thin out crowded branches to allow sunlight to penetrate and shape by cutting back the previous year's growth to healthy buds or side shoots. This encourages new growth and better fruit production if the plant is fruit-bearing. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Korea","China","Japan","Taiwan"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Rubus pectinellus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, in too much shade, its growth might slow down, and the foliage may become less dense. Light shaping can be done to maintain its aesthetic form, focusing on cutting back to a lateral branch or bud. Avoid heavy pruning, as it can stress the plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18185,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polystichum vestitum, like many ferns, prefers consistently moist soil. It requires regular watering to keep the soil evenly moist without being waterlogged. During the growing season, watering should be more frequent, usually once to twice a week depending on the environment's humidity and temperature. In cooler months or if humidity is high, reduce the watering frequency to prevent root rot. Ensure the plant has good drainage to prevent water from stagnating around the roots. Always check the top inch of the soil; if it's dry, it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polystichum vestitum thrives in shaded to partially shaded environments. It prefers dappled sunlight similar to its natural understory habitat. Direct morning sun or diffused light during the day is ideal, but avoid harsh afternoon sunlight, which can scorch its delicate fronds. If grown indoors, place the plant near a north or east-facing window where it can receive indirect light. Adjusting its position seasonally to accommodate changes in sunlight intensity can help maintain optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Polystichum vestitum, pruning mainly involves removing any dead or damaged fronds to maintain the plant's health and appearance. Pruning can be done at any time during the growing season, but avoid excessive pruning in the late fall or winter as the plant is more dormant. Use sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to cut the fronds at the base, close to where they emerge from the soil. This not only encourages healthy new growth but also improves air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Prickly Shield Fern","description":"Polystichum vestitum, commonly known as the prickly shield fern, is a hardy, evergreen or semi-evergreen ground fern.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand","Australia"],"other_name":["Prickly Shield Fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Polystichum vestitum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18785,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senecio hispidulus prefers well-draining soil, so water it thoroughly and then allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings. The frequency of watering will depend on the humidity and temperature of your space. In its growing season, which is generally spring and summer, you might need to water it once a week. During the dormant period in fall and winter, reduce watering to every two to three weeks. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so ensure excess water drains off and the pot does not sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senecio hispidulus enjoys bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially morning sun, but should be protected from harsh midday rays, which can scorch the leaves. A spot near a south or east-facing window is ideal. If you notice the plant becoming leggy or the leaves losing their color, it might be an indication that it's not receiving enough light. Conversely, if the leaves are developing brown spots, it may be receiving too much direct sunlight and might need to be relocated to a slightly less lit area."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio hispidulus involves trimming back any leggy or overgrown stems to maintain a compact, bushy shape. It is best to prune during the growing season, in spring or early summer. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged stems with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. Regular pruning encourages denser foliage and healthier growth. If flowering becomes sparse, cutting back after flowering can also promote new blooms. Always ensure your tools are clean to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hill Fireweed","description":"Senecio hispidulus, the Hill Fireweed or Rough Groundsel, is a species of flowering plant in the daisy family. It is found in many parts of Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Hill Fireweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Senecio hispidulus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19679,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lysimachia europaea, also known as chickweed wintergreen, prefers consistently moist soil. It thrives in areas where it can receive regular watering, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During dry periods, especially in summer, increase watering frequency to maintain the required soil moisture. Be cautious not to let the plant sit in water; the soil should be damp, not soggy. Monitor the plant for wilting or excessive leaf drop, signs that it may require more water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lysimachia europaea thrives in dappled sunlight or partial shade, similar to its natural forest floor environment. It can tolerate full shade but may not flower as prolifically under such conditions. Direct, harsh sunlight can be detrimental, leading to leaf scorch, so it's best to avoid exposing the plant to afternoon sun, especially in hotter climates. Ideal planting spots are under the canopy of larger trees or shrubs where it can receive filtered light. Balance is key, ensuring the plant gets enough light to thrive but not so much that it becomes stressed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lysimachia europaea is relatively straightforward and mainly involves removing dead or damaged leaves to promote healthy growth. It doesn't require extensive pruning due to its low-growing nature. Periodically check for and trim any spent flower spikes to encourage new blooms and a tidier appearance. Since this plant spreads via rhizomes, keeping an eye on peripheral growth is also beneficial to prevent unwanted spread. Pruning is best done in early spring before new growth begins or in late autumn after the plant has finished blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arctic Starflower","description":"Lysimachia europaea (formerly known as Trientalis europaea) is a flowering plant in the primrose family Primulaceae, called by the common name chickweed-wintergreen or arctic starflower. It is a small herbaceous perennial plant with one or more whorls of leaves on a single slender erect stem. It is about one third of a foot high (10Â cm), giving it its generic name. The broad lanceolate leaves are pale green but take on a copper hue in late summer....","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Arctic Starflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lysimachia europaea"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19183,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sedum nuttallii, like many succulent species, is drought-tolerant and does not require frequent watering. It's best to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the spring and summer, water the plant thoroughly and then wait until the soil is dry to the touch before watering again. In the fall and winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy, watering only enough to prevent the leaves from shriveling. Be cautious of overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Always ensure that the plant is in a pot with drainage holes to facilitate excess water escape."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sedum nuttallii thrives best in full sun exposure, which means it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. This succulent prefers bright, direct light and will grow well in a location with unobstructed, full sunlight. It can tolerate partial shade but may not flower as profusely and could become leggy if it doesn't receive enough light. If you are keeping it indoors, a south-facing window would be ideal. When moving the plant outdoors or to a brighter location, do so gradually to allow it to adjust and avoid sunburn on the leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Sedum nuttallii is generally minimal, but it can benefit from the occasional removal of dead or damaged leaves. Trim these leaves close to the stem using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to encourage healthy growth. If the plant becomes leggy, you can trim back the stems to maintain a more compact shape. Pruning should ideally be done during its growing season in spring or early summer. Avoid heavy pruning during the winter or when the plant is not actively growing. Pruning also helps in maintaining the plant's appearance and stimulating new growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"yellow stonecrop","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["yellow stonecrop"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Sedum nuttallii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18580,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Homalanthus populifolius, commonly known as the Bleeding Heart tree, prefers consistently moist soil but does not tolerate waterlogged conditions. Water the plant thoroughly once the top inch of soil feels dry, ensuring that excess water drains away to avoid root rot. During the warmer growing seasons, the plant may require more frequent watering, so keep an eye on soil moisture levels. In the cooler months, reduce watering to prevent overly wet soil, allowing it to dry out slightly between waterings without letting it dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Homalanthus populifolius grows best in partial shade to full sun conditions, but it typically prefers indirect or dappled sunlight. In hotter climates, it benefits from protection against the harsh midday sun to prevent leaf scorching. If you're growing it indoors or in a shaded location, ensure it receives bright, filtered light for most of the day to promote healthy growth. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even exposure to sunlight, encouraging balanced growth and color. Outside, choose a location with morning sun and afternoon shade for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Homalanthus populifolius can help maintain its shape and remove any damaged or dead branches. Light pruning is usually sufficient and is best done in late winter or early spring before the new growth appears. When pruning, use clean and sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts, and remove any crossing or crowded branches to improve air circulation. It is also a good practice to remove any suckers that may grow from the base to promote a healthier, single-trunk structure, if desired."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Bleeding Heart","description":"Homalanthus populifolius, the bleeding heart or Queensland poplar, is an Australian rainforest plant. It often appears in areas of rainforest disturbance. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19770,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vachellia schaffneri, commonly known as Schaffner's or Twisted Acacia, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. It is suited to arid and semi-arid conditions and should be watered sparingly. Allow the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is crucial to ensure good drainage and avoid waterlogged conditions. In its native habitat, it only receives water through seasonal rainfall, so mimicking these natural conditions will help maintain its health and resilience."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vachellia schaffneri thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to grow optimally. This plant is highly adapted to sunny, dry conditions and can tolerate high temperatures typical of its native arid environment. While it can survive in partial shade, insufficient sunlight can lead to sparse foliage and reduced blooming. Placing it in an area with ample sunlight exposure will ensure robust growth and maintain the plant's vigor. Therefore, choose a bright and sunny spot in your garden or landscape for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vachellia schaffneri should be done in late winter or early spring to shape the tree and remove any dead or diseased branches. Minimal pruning is generally required since its natural shape is quite attractive. Focus on removing crossing branches that might impede growth or airflow. Pruning can also help maintain a desired size or manage its sometimes aggressive spread in appropriate growing zones. Ensure you use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, reducing the risk of disease. Avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Schaffner's acacia","description":"Vachellia schaffneri (twisted acacia or Schaffner's acacia) is a tree native to Mexico and the United States (Texas).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Texas"],"other_name":["Schaffner's acacia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Vachellia schaffneri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In general, allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between watering to prevent root rot, especially in well-draining soil conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Candle Nut Tree thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and protect the roots from extreme heat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clematis flammula thrives in full sunlight, which means it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Ensuring the top part of the plant receives ample sunlight while the bottom part is cooler is the key to successful growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis flammula is essential for maintaining its shape and health. This clematis typically belongs to Group 3, which means it blooms on new growth. Prune back the stems to about 12 inches from the ground in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged wood as you prune. This encourages vigorous growth and abundant flowering. If you wish to control its size and spread more, additional trimming after flowering can help manage its shape and prevent it from becoming too overgrown."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fragrant virgin's-bower","description":"Clematis flammula is a temperate liana known by the common name fragrant virgin's bower. During its growing season, typically from spring to early autumn, ensure the soil doesnâ€™t dry out. Regular watering is essential, especially in hot or dry spells, to prevent wilting. However, be cautious not to overwater, as Clematis dislikes waterlogged conditions which can lead to root rot. In winter, reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and keep roots cool in hotter months. Adjust watering frequency based on local climate and soil conditions for optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clematis grata thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal flowering, aim for at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate some shade, too little sunlight may result in fewer blooms. Ideally, plant Clematis with its roots shaded or mulched, while the foliage remains in the sun. This can be achieved by planting ground cover or low-growing shrubs at its base. Morning sun and afternoon shade can be beneficial in particularly hot climates, preventing excessive heat stress and ensuring a healthy, blooming plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis grata is crucial to encourage vigorous growth and abundant flowering. Since this species blooms on new wood, it belongs to Group 3, which requires pruning in late winter or early spring. Cut back all stems to a pair of strong buds about 12-18 inches above the ground. This pruning helps rejuvenate the plant and promotes stronger growth during the growing season. Remove any dead, damaged, or weak stems to enhance air circulation and prevent disease. Regular pruning also helps maintain the desired size and shape of the clematis."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Charming Clematis","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia"],"other_name":["Charming Clematis"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Clematis grata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Late winter to early spring is the ideal time for pruning. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation. It's also beneficial to prune selectively to maintain an open canopy and enhance flowering potential. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant. Instead, focus on gentle shaping and thinning out dense areas to ensure the tree remains healthy and robust."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas mountain laurel","description":"Dermatophyllum secundiflorum is a species of flowering shrub or small tree in the pea family, Fabaceae, that is native to the southwestern United States (Texas, New Mexico) and Mexico (Chihuahua and Coahuila south to Hidalgo, Puebla and QuerÃ©taro). Common names include Texas mountain laurel, Texas mescalbean, frijolito, and frijolillo. During its growth period in late spring and summer, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It is important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Reduced watering is necessary during the plant's dormancy in winter. Always ensure adequate drainage to avoid water accumulation, and consider mulching to help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus crataegifolius thrives best in full to partial sunlight. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to promote optimal growth and fruiting. However, it can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates, where a bit of afternoon shade might prevent the plant from becoming too stressed. Providing the plant with insufficient light can result in reduced flower and fruit production. Therefore, selecting a location with ample sunlight exposure is crucial for healthy development and a bountiful harvest."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus crataegifolius involves removing any dead, damaged, or diseased canes at ground level to promote healthy growth. In late winter or early spring, before new growth begins, it's also beneficial to thin out any overcrowded canes to improve air circulation, which helps prevent disease. For fruit production, prune the floricanes (second-year canes) after they have fruited, cutting them back to the ground to encourage new primocanes (first-year canes) to grow. Regular pruning ensures a tidy appearance and improves fruit yield."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Korean Raspberry","description":"Rubus crataegifolius, also called Korean raspberry, is a species of raspberry native to East Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["East Asia"],"other_name":["Korean Raspberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Anthracnose","Cane blight"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rubus crataegifolius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If direct sunlight isn't available, fluorescent grow lights can be used to supplement the natural light, maintaining healthy foliage growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dracophyllum rosmarinifolium is generally minimal and should be done to remove dead or damaged leaves and stems to improve its appearance and promote healthier growth. The best time to prune is during the plant's dormant period, which is late winter to early spring. Use clean, sharp gardening shears to make precise cuts. If cultivated indoors, a dimly lit room or indirect sunlight exposure is best to avoid drying out. High heat and direct sunlight can be detrimental, so maintaining a cool, shadowy area is optimal. However, if growing these mushrooms for study or in a controlled environment, you might consider removing any decomposing parts or contaminants that could affect their growth. Always use clean and sterile tools to avoid introducing pathogens, and handle the mushrooms gently to avoid damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"salmon pinkgill","description":"Entoloma quadratum is a species of agaric fungus in the family Entolomataceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18286,"attracts":["Birds","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hyphaene petersiana, commonly known as the Makalani palm, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. During its initial growth phase, it should be watered moderately to aid in the establishment of the root system. Once established, you can reduce watering frequency, making sure to allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot, especially since this plant is adapted to thrive in dry, sandy soils. In its natural habitat, it can rely on infrequent rainfall, so simulating such conditions will aid in its healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hyphaene petersiana thrives in full sun conditions and should be placed in a location where it can receive at least several hours of direct sunlight each day. It is well-suited to sunny, arid environments, reflecting its native habitat. If grown indoors or in a less sunny area, attempt to provide as much light as possible to ensure healthy growth. Insufficient sunlight may result in slower growth and weaken the plant, so it is crucial to ensure it is not shaded out by larger trees or structures if planted in a garden setting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Hyphaene petersiana should be minimized and primarily focused on removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain a tidy and healthy appearance. Avoid over-pruning, as this can stress the plant. It is advisable to trim close to the trunk, but care should be taken not to cut into the trunk itself, as this can damage the plant. This palm does not require regular pruning and should be allowed to maintain its natural form, trimming only as needed to remove fronds that may pose a structural hazard or detract from the palm's aesthetic."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Makalani Palm","description":"The Real fan palm (Hyphaene petersiana), locally known as the Makalani palm, is a palm tree native to the subtropical, low-lying regions of south central Africa. It is found in Burundi, Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Tanzania, Angola, Mozambique, Malawi, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Namibia and the northern and north-eastern Transvaal.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southern Africa"],"other_name":["Makalani Palm"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Hyphaene petersiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19774,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cyclocybe parasitica, commonly known as native morel or walnut roundhead, is a type of mushroom rather than a plant, and it typically thrives in humid environments. It is important to maintain a consistently moist substrate when cultivating this species. Be sure that the growing medium is damp but not overly saturated as excessive moisture can lead to fungal diseases. Watering can be achieved by misting, ensuring the substrate does not dry out. In natural conditions, this fungus enjoys environments with high humidity, so replicating this in a cultivation setting is crucial for its development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"In its natural habitat, Cyclocybe parasitica grows in shaded, forested areas, often on dead or decaying wood. For cultivation, mimic this environment by providing indirect sunlight or maintaining the fungus in a shaded area to replicate its natural dappled light conditions. Direct sunlight can be too intense and reduce moisture levels, which are crucial for optimal mushroom development. Direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, so itâ€™s important to place this orchid in a location where it receives filtered sunlight, such as behind a sheer curtain or near an east-facing window where it gets morning light. If possible, provide additional artificial light to mimic its natural habitat conditions, especially during the winter months when daylight is limited. Insufficient light may hinder its flowering, so pay close attention to leaf color; overly dark leaves often indicate a need for more light, while yellowing may suggest too much light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Orthochilus ecristatus primarily involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged leaves to promote healthy growth and airflow around the plant. It is best to prune just after the flowering season when blooms have faded. Use sterilized scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts. Focus on cutting back stems that are yellowing or have shown no new growth. Ensure not to over-prune, as orchids generally require minimal pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Giant Orchid","description":"Orthochilus ecristatus, or giant orchid, is a terrestrial species of orchid native to Cuba and to the southeastern United States (from Louisiana to North Carolina). In hotter climates, providing protection from intense midday sun can help prevent damage. While it can adapt to lower light conditions, ensure some exposure to sunlight to promote healthy growth. If grown indoors, place it near a bright window but away from direct sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pseudopanax colensoi is generally not necessary unless you're controlling its size or removing dead or damaged branches. If pruning is needed, it's best done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. This timing minimizes stress on the plant. When pruning, use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, and remove no more than a third of the plant at a time to avoid shocking it. Pruning encourages a bushier growth habit, so periodically trim to maintain the desired shape and healthy structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain Five Finger","description":"Pseudopanax colensoi is a species of evergreen plant. This species is native to New Zealand. Monitoring sun exposure and adjusting its location can ensure it receives appropriate lighting without the risk of damage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pectenia plumbea is generally minimal, primarily involving the removal of dead or decaying leaves to encourage healthy growth and prevent fungal issues. While it can adapt to a variety of light conditions, providing ample sunlight ensures the healthiest growth and most abundant flowering. Ideal planting locations include coastal and tropical areas where it naturally grows, but ensure it isn't in too shaded an area, as this can impact its vibrancy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Scaevola taccada is important for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushiness. Regular pruning also helps to control its size and maintain a desirable shape, ensuring the shrub stays healthy and attractive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"beach naupaka","description":"Scaevola taccada, also known as beach cabbage, sea lettuce, beach naupaka, naupaka kahakai (Hawaiian), magoo (Divehi), merambong (Malay), bapaceda or papatjeda (Moluccan Islands), ngahu (Tongan) is a flowering plant in the family Goodeniaceae found in coastal locations in the tropical areas of the Indo-Pacific. Water the plant moderately, allowing the top 1-2 inches of soil to dry out between waterings. Generally, in the active growing season (spring and summer), you might need to water weekly, depending on the climate and the soil's drainage. In winter, reduce watering since the plant's growth slows down. Always check the soil moisture level before watering to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erica hirtiflora thrives best with plenty of bright sunlight, making full sun exposure ideal. It benefits from direct sunlight for at least six hours a day to ensure healthy growth and vibrant blooming. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf burn. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. Insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so if growing indoors, consider supplemental grow lights if natural light is lacking."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erica hirtiflora helps maintain its shape and encourages bushiness. Prune the plant after its flowering period, typically in late winter or early spring. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches first. You can also trim back any overly long or unruly stems to promote a more compact growth habit. Avoid cutting into old wood, as ericas may not regrow from it. Instead, focus on pruning back to just above a leaf node on newer growth. Regular pruning also helps to remove spent flower heads and stimulate new blooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hairyflower Heath","description":"Erica hirtiflora (or the hairy-flower heath) is a species of Erica that was naturally restricted to the south-western corner of the Western Cape, South Africa around the city of Cape Town.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Hairyflower Heath"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Erica hirtiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In particularly hot climates, afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching and protect the plant from excessive heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Veronica macrocarpa should be done primarily in the spring to remove any dead or damaged stems, promoting new growth and maintaining a neat appearance. After the plant has finished flowering, spent blooms can be cut back to encourage a tidier look and potentially extend the blooming period. In autumn, cutting back the plant to about half its height can help prepare it for the winter season. Always use sharp, sterilized pruning tools to prevent disease transmission and ensure clean cuts. During prolonged dry spells, occasional deep watering will benefit the plant. However, ensure the soil drains well to prevent root rot. Over-watering can lead to poor growth and susceptibility to disease. Adjust watering frequency depending on your climate, with less water needed in cooler months and possibly more during hot, dry summer days."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hakea salicifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to enhance its flowering capacity and overall robust growth. In cooler climates, full sun exposure ensures the plant stays warm enough and supports healthy development. However, in hotter, arid climates, partial afternoon shade can protect it from intense midday sun, preventing leaf scorch and moisture loss. While it can tolerate some shade, a more shaded environment might lead to less prolific flowering and a leggier growth habit, making full sun preferable when possible."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hakea salicifolia is generally only necessary to maintain its shape or remove any unruly or dead branches. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring before new growth appears. Use sharp, clean tools to make clean cuts and prevent disease. Remove dead or damaged stems and any crossing branches that may affect airflow through the plant's canopy. Light trimming will promote a bushier appearance, enhancing its aesthetic value in the garden. Avoid heavy pruning as it may reduce flowering the following season.
